awd_titl_txt: Robust and Distributed Statistical Learning from Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Big Data are ubiquitous in many areas of science, engineering, social sciences, and the humanities, and have significant impact in terms of technological innovation and economic development.    This project seeks to introduce effective methods for robust high-dimensional statistical inference that are insensitive to the potential poor quality of big data, and to develop distributed estimation that is needed for Big Data analysis, computing, and optimization.  The research will address several robust and distributed statistical inference problems for Big Data in genomics, genetics, neuroscience, machine learning, economics, and finance.   The project will advance our understanding of molecular mechanisms, biological processes, genetic associations, brain functions, and economic and financial risk.  Integration of research and education will be achieved through the involvement of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, and the development of publicly available computer code for robust and distributed analysis of Big Data with sound theoretical support.  Working closely with industrial partners, the research will lead to increased collaborations between academia and industry.  

The project will lead to the development of novel statistical theory, methods, and algorithms for robust statistical inference from high-dimensional statistics and Big Data.  The first aim seeks to introduce a simple and widely applicable principle for robust inference via an appropriate shrinkage of observed data or loss functions.  This reduces the influence of outliers and heavy-tailed distributions, and weakens the moment conditions from sub-Gaussian distributions to bounded second moments for regression or fourth moments for covariance estimation.  The research includes plans to systematically develop the theory and methods for robust estimation of high-dimension means, and implementation of these methods to control false discovery rates in large scale inference for gene and transcripts selection, robust regularization of covariance and precision matrices, and their applications to robust principal component analysis, factor analysis and high-dimensional hypothesis testing.  In addition, robust sparse regression, model selection, and low-rank matrix recovery will also be investigated.  The second aim focuses on making the proposed robust procedures applicable to the Big Data environment via the development of distributed estimation and inference.  In particular, divide-and-conquer methods will be used to distribute the computation to node machines and to solve privacy and data ownership issues.  Approaches to reduce the information loss due to the distributed computation for likelihood based models via partial communication of the Hessian matrices will be investigated.   Two important classes of problems, trace regression and principal component analysis, will be used to illustrate the proposed methods.

por.por_cntn:
Enormous datasets are routinely collected in biological science, natural science, engineering, as well as social science.  They have huge impact on statistical analysis and computing.  A common feature of Big Data is heavy-tailed distributions of some variables, which are pandemic to high-dimensional data. At the same time Big Data are often distributed in multiple centers due to privacy, storage as well as computation issues.  This project developed novel statistical theory, methods, and algorithms for robust statistical inference from high-dimensional Big Data and introduced distributed estimation and federated learning algorithms that are critical for Big Data analysis, computing, and optimization.

The project introduced a simple and widely applicable principle for robust inference via an appropriate shrinkage of observed data or loss functions.  This reduces the influence of outliers and heavy-tailed distributions, weakens the conditions from sub-Gaussian distributions to merely bounded second moments for regression or fourth moments for covariance estimation or even weaker, and hence significantly widens the scope of applicability of the state-of-art statistical machine learning algorithms.  The PI developed systematically the theory and methods for robust estimation of high-dimensional means and use them to control false discovery rates in large scale inference such as gene and transcripts selection, for robust regularization of covariance and precision matrices for understanding financial risks and genomics networks. The scope of the study is expanded further to other important problems such as robust principal component analysis, factor analysis, large-scale hypothesis testing, robust sparse regression, model selection, and low-rank matrix recovery for recommender systems and online sales.

This project also addressed robust Big Data analysis when data are distributed in multiple centers. The divide-and-conquer methods were used to distribute the computation to node machines and to solve privacy and data ownership issues.  Its capacity and limitations were thoroughly investigated, and the studies prompted the PI to develop a widely applicable communication efficient and statistical accurate algorithms for machine learning and causal inference. Two important classes of problems, principal component analysis and survival analysis, were used as the showcases of the studies.

This project output over 40 publications in top statistical and other scientific journals, covering a wide range of topics, from statistical machine learning and financial risks to biomedical studies and business analytics.  The grant benefited directly and indirectly 28 Ph.D. students (10 females, 18 graduated, 9 ongoing).  In addition, 22 senior theses (10 females) for undergraduates have been directed, all their theses related to using statistical machine learning methods to address important problems of social concerns, particularly in finance, economics, and other decision sciences. Three (1 female) high-school senior students completed an internship, contributed to and benefited from the research.
